Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Highly-available Power Supply through Distributed Generation Technologies: Reliability Analysis Framework Based on Operation Under Critical Conditions

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to understand the reliability behavior of microgrid-based ultra-reliable power systems in extreme conditions. This objective is part of a broader career plan that focuses on improving electric power supply availability through dc microgrids. The approach involves an analytic methodology that estimates failure probability and expected failure duration during hurricanes and earthquakes by relating these events? intensity with location-dependent infrastructure vulnerabilities. Results are verified through simulations and compared with past events? outcomes. The analysis uses telecommunications power plants as a reference technology because of their similarities with dc microgrids.

The Intellectual Merit resides in the introduction of a reliability framework that uses non-homogeneous Markov models. Transitions among states are characterized by the time varying failure and repair rates of each key element in microgrids energy supply infrastructures. The use of microgrids to achieve high availability constitutes a radical shift from the paradigm of relying on energy-based backup systems. This research also advances hurricanes characterization by introducing a new measure of intensity.

The Broader Impacts extend into improving electric power supply resiliency and national security, potentially reducing the loss of lives after disasters, and creating interdisciplinary collaboration opportunities with scientists studying disasters. This project will leverage the interest on disasters to attract students into the electric power area and to support the development of a power electronics research and educational program with participation opportunities for minority students. Research dissemination and education plans involve outreach goals targeting a diverse audience, including peers, students, and the community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
It has been known that power grids—a critical infrastructure integrated to modern society fabric—generally present a poor performance during natural disasters. During damage assessments conducted as part of this project after several hurricanes and earthquakes it was observed that power grids are very fragile systems in which little damage may lead to long outages affecting large areas (Fig. 1). Since this poor performance originates in part in the centralized generation and transmission, and control architectures of conventional power grids, this project pioneered the idea of using distributed local power generation in relatively small power grids called microgrids.

In the past, there have been statements indicating that microgrid’s availability—the portion of the time a system is expected to be operating—was better than that of conventional power grids. However, at that time, models able to demonstrate such statement were incomplete. One of the issues with these models is that even in the very few cases when availability of the local power generators was considered, the infrastructure (called lifelines) needed for delivering fuel to these sources was not considered—e.g. availability of natural gas pipelines for microturbines. As a result, it could not be affirm that microgrids availability was better than that of conventional electric power grids. Although some local power sources, such as photovoltaics (PV) or wind generators do not need lifelines to operate, their availability models were equally incomplete. Moreover, use of energy storage were not considered in availability models and reliance on conventional reliability metrics used in distribution portions of electric grids were not applicable for microgrids. In essence, when the notion of microgrids was in its infancy this project introduced the study of the needs and approaches related to microgrids application in order to address issues with conventional power grids during natural disasters. It is only after Hurricane Sandy, that the focus of this project has become a mainstream concept because of the realization of the significant benefits that well designed microgrids could have during disaster conditions.

Overall, this project has had a profound impact on its discipline as it is the first study with an integral approach to evaluate microgrids availability during natural disasters. This integral approach includes the effect of all components of a microgrid, such as energy storage, and also of external factors, such as lifelines performance during natural disasters. In addition to an extensive publication list, outcomes of this project addressing its intellectual merit and supporting its significant broader impact are:

-        A significant database and records of lifelines and power grids performance during hurricanes and recent earthquakes was developed. Performance of these infrastructure systems was documented based on information from damage assessments, which provided an empirical analytical approach that opposes the far more common approach of using established abstract general models to run simulations. Effect of natural disasters on operating microgrids (Fig. 2) and on renewable energy sources systems (Fig. 3) were documented for the first time. Natural disasters studied based on damage assessments by the PI include hurricanes and tropical storms (TS) Katrina, Dolly, Gustav, Ike, Hermine (TS), Irene (TS), Isaac and Sandy (Fig. 4). Three earthquakes were also studied with the same approach: February 2010 in Chile, February 2011 in Christchurch, New Zealand and March 2011 in Japan (Fig. 5).
